review_blob: 500ml bottle from Jumbo Costanera Center. Pours a deep dark amber color with some orange hues. Head is big (even with some gushing after opening) and leaves a good and irregular lacing. Aroma is a classic: banana, wheat and mild spices. A bit of coriander, peach and orange peel. Slight hints of toffee in the back. Not bad. Taste is quite tart for a Hefe. Its the tart-est one Ive tried with little sweetness. Fruity flavors add up to the main bready and grainy character. Pineapple, melon and green pear flavors. Nice. Medium body, lively but thin carbonation. Finish is a bit watery and leads to a short-lived spicy aftertaste. Not a bad Hefe at all, tart and different, pretty much on par with Erdinger.

500ml can from Jumbo Costanera Center. Pours a dark mahogany color with a big creamy beige head (almost nitro-looking) that diminishes slowly and laces well. Aroma is malty, a bit nutty with lightly toasted notes as well as some chocolate, cereals, dark bread and, unfortunately metal and rust. Taste is sweet, but balanced. Notes of nuts, a touch of chocolate, straw, grains and toasted white bread. Not very intense, but nice and easy to drink. Medium body and carbonation. Smooth but nothing remarkable. An adequate Schwarzbier. Just not anywhere near top of the line.

330ml bottle from Jumbo Costanera Center. Pours a dark copper, almost ruby color with a big light brown fizzy head that diminishes after a couple of minutes into a good lacing. Aroma is malty and spicy with good intensity: Notes of raisins, plums, prunes, brown sugar, some toffee, pepper and a touch of Jgermeister herbs. Interesting and fine. Taste is rich and complex with a nice sweet and spicy mixture. Well balanced. Hops barely discernible but there. Medium tartness compliments the sweet and spicy flavor. Nice. Medium body, alcohol well disguised. Carbonation is a bit thin. Overall this is a very nice, tasty and complex Belgian dark ale.

330 ml bottle from Jumbo Costanera Center Pours a reddish brown color with a beige head that diminishes quickly and leaves a small lacing. Aroma is a bit strange with strong cardboard touches. Notes of grains, caramel, prunes, herring, toasted bread. Some melanoidins but not strong enough. The fish-herring hints are a throwback. Taste is mildly toasted, sweet but thankfully not cloying. Low intensity. Sugary flavors, bready and toasted traces appear and disappear quickly. Not so bad. Mouthfeel is sadly thin, weak. Small body, low to medium carbonation. Short aftertaste. An insufficient, flawed, dark lager.

330ml bottle from Jumbo Costanera Center Pours a clear golden color with a minimal white head that disappears quickly leaving no lacing. Aroma is mostly malty (Cascade hops? I didnt feel any), grainy and bready in equal parts. Notes of cereals, bread, a slight hint of sugar and some grasses. One-dimensional and a bit weak. Taste is somewhat better. Light and predominantly sweet, grainy without bitter counterbalance. Nothing remarkable but clean enough. Light body, medium carbonation, soft and easy drinking thirst quencher. My first Korean beer I think. A prototypical unremarkable sweet-ish lager.

500ml bottle from Jumbo Costanera Center. Pours a cloudy amber/orange color with a massive white pillowy head that diminishes slowly and leaves a film. Aroma is mild, wheaty and a bit spicy. Predominant notes of wheat, banana, spices, grains, dough and white bread. Not bad at all, but not really expressive. Taste is quite neutral, doughy, bready with some light tartness and evanescent fruity flavors. Hints of spice come through but never unfold completely. Light body, low to medium fizzy carbonation. Short, quick finish. Neutral aftertaste. A simple, by-the-book Hefe-weizen, far away from the best of their kind.

Bottle from Jumbo Costanera Center. Pours a clear and strong golden color with a thin but persistent white head that leaves a film and a nice lacing. Aroma is incredibly strong in Chardonnay wine character. Notes are mostly winey and sparkling wine but evanescent hints of pineapple, grapes and peach can be felt. Taste is lightly sweet with about the same level of tartness, mildly fruity and strong in white wine and white grapes. Good quality Chardonnay in the flavor. Good. Light body, easy to drink and very smooth. Light carbonation. A bit sticky. Crazy stuff, more than a Saison, it feels like a Chardonnay-Saison crossbreeding.

330ml bottle from Club de Cervezas. Bonus. Thank you, Eduardo. Pours a slightly hazy mahogany/crimson color with a medium off-white head that diminishes slowly and laces well. Aroma is fruity with cherries obviously dominating, but it also has some beer qualities. Notes of sweet and sour cherries, oak, cherry liquor, marmalade and yoghurt, christmas cake and some candy. Taste is sweet but well-balanced. Some sour hints come through the densely fruity touches. Sweetness is present but not overpowering at all. The alcohol rounds up very well with strong liquorish character. Sticky texture, low to medium carbonation, long aftertaste. A delicious beer, but not nearly as sour as I expected.

250ml bottle from Club de Cervezas. Pours a clear amber color with a medium but fast diminishing off-white head. Aroma is a bit sour but mostly shy in its expresiveness. Some melon, green apple and pear mixed up with touches of funk, old bread and cucumber. Restrained. Taste is also low intensity. A bit tart, a bit fruity, even a bit veggie. Not really complex, but all of these are just angles of the same semi-sour, semi-sweet taste. Hints of apples, pears, some funk and dough. Alright. Light to medium body, soft and fine carbonation. Low aftertaste. Decent enough, Im glad I tried it. My introduction to the style but Im sure its a really basic and dull specimen.

250ml bottle from Club de Cervezas. Pours a deep ruby red color with a minimal pinkish fizzy head that vanishes after a few seconds. Aroma is basically cherries, but quite clean, nice without being sugary or syrupy. Its a bit lactic and fresh. Taste is pleasant, mild tartness with some non intrusve sweetness. Good balance and the cherries integrate amazingly well. Its not something I would kill to drink, but its one of the few good Krieks Ive tried. Medium body, carbonation is soft but is presence is shown very well. Easy to drink. Smooth and mild. A very pleasant Kriek, much better than the cheap fruit lambics I tried before like Chapeau or Floris.

250ml bottle from Club de Cervezas. Pours a cloudy yellow color with a big white creamy head that shows moderate retention. Aroma is very estery, fruity and floral, with some spicy touches. Notes of soft citrus, both lemony and orangey, a bit of coriander, pineapple and passionfruit. Some green and mildly hoppy touches of fresh green leaves, bread and hay. Taste is spicy with some initial sweetness, moderate bitter hints and a dry-ish finish. Notes of white wine, spices, orange, pineapple and bread. Interesting. High carbonation, light to medium body. Refreshing. Somewhat close to Belgian Witbiers but still a Saison. Quite good but nothing to write home about.

330ml bottle from Club de Cervezas. Pours a bright but hazy orange-golden color with a small white head that diminishes quickly. Aroma is intensely hoppy, IPA-like, with huge fruity character. Notes of tangerines, tangelos, orange peel, tropical fruits, mandarines and spices. A bit peppery and earthy. Quite complex and enticing. Gets better and better. Taste is very bitter, strong and fruity. Sweetness is light in te beginning with some tangelo flavor turning into a bitter citrusy, earthy and peppery bomb. Fruitiness dominates throughout until that powerful end that shows moderate astringency. Long, everlasting aftertaste. Light to medium body. High carbonation. Nice. An intensely aromatic and flavorful IPA-like APA. One of the best APAs Ive tried and deserving of all the hype.

33cl bottle gift from my Swedish friend Marcus Edensky. Pours bright and a bit hazy golden color with a big and consistent frothy white head that diminishes slowly and laces perfectly well. Aroma is hoppy in a spicy and citrusy way. Medium intensity but well defined. Notes of grapefruit, pepper, rosemary, lime, lemongrass, green herbs, conifers, some peach and sweet-ish touches from the malty backbone. Nice. Taste is definitely bitter with green fruity flavors (prickly pear, mellon, green beeries) contributing mild acidity and sweetness. Its milder than the aroma, but pleasant nevertheless. Light body, easy to drink. Medium carbonation. A very good Session IPA, Im happy I had the chance of tasting.

330ml bottle, gift from Sweden. Thank you, my friend, Marcus Edensky. Pours a hazy amber, almost orange color with a nice big off-white head that shows good retention and leaves a good lacing. Aroma is freshly fruity with some herbal touches. Predominant notes include grapefruit, orange, grass, prickly pear and lots of flowers. Additional hints of honey and palm syrup. Some citrus, but not much. I didnt find the Cascade hops very expressive on this one. Still, not bad. Taste is medium bitter with enough sweet taste of tropical fruits, some citrus, and cereal grains. The grassy and grapefruity traces rule here anyway. It finishes abruptly leaving a slightly dull aftertaste. Light to medium body, carbonation is really soft. Seems like an APA to me more than an IPA. Its ok, but needs more expression.
beer_name: Skelderwikens this Ale is India Pale

review_blob: 750ml bottle from Gallaghers Beer World/El Irlands. It says brewed and bottled by Mikkeller + Three Floyds at De Proef Brouwerij. BBD: 09-04-2020. Pours a hazy amber color with orange and pink hues and a medium white head that shows remarkably long retention and leaves a gorgeous film. Aroma is well hopped but with a very spread-open malt presence. Fruity notes dominate with orange, tangerines, grapefruit, pommegranate, peach, papaya, raspberry, strawberry marmalade and overripe mango. Grainy hints and molasses come to the fore transitioning into some greener touches of resin and grass. Delightful. Taste is sweet, sticky and punchy with alcohol. Massive intensity, the 750ml are too much for a single person. Maybe too much for two. Sugary flavors, especially candy sugar, dominate the fruitiness even though the brewers attempted to give more room to the hops adding large amounts of them. Serious sweetness. Big body, full mouthfeel. Smooth texture, low to mid carbonation. Long finish and really sticky aftertaste. Intense and powerful Barley Wine... but overly sweet. Youll love it if you drink just one little 50ml sample, but if you drink the equivalent to a normal bottle (330ml or 12 fl.oz.) the sweetness will be too much. The score reflects that since a 50ml sample would have gotten about a 4. A larger sample deserves around a 3 or 3.1. Now give me a well made Czech Pilsner.

750ml bottle from Gallaghers Beer World/El Irlands. Pours a cloudy orange-amber color with a small white frothy head that lasts for long. Aroma is very fruity with a fair amount of resinous hops. Notes are mainly of berries, cherries, tropical fruits and a bit of sweet citrus with en resin and spruce encompassing around. No rice notes at all despite its use as an ingredient. Nice. Taste is very sweet, intense and fruity. Some bitter hints can be felt for balance but it shows mostly flavors of red berries, peach, mango and other overripe fruits. Marmalade, sugars and esters. Some alcoholic kick gives it a true Barley Wine effect. Almost full bodied, carbonation is soft. Prolonged aftertaste. Another nice fruity Barley Wine that doesnt push too far away from its similar sisters Bogoop and Majsgoop.

750ml bottle from Gallaghers Beer World/El Irlands. Pours a hazy reddish orange color with a small but thick creamy head that lingers. Aroma is intensely fruity but relatively simple. Mango, peach, pommegranate and grapefruit dominate throughout. Maybe a bit of sweet citrus and little malt presence. Taste continues the fruity sweetness but adds a bitter feeling towards the end. The flavors remain within the tropical fruit and sweet citrus comfy zone but theres a bitter hint thats not completely refined. Alcohol well integrated, medium to big body. Smooth. Neither super-intense nor extremely-complex. Just a competent hoppy and well-made Barley Wine.

330ml bottle from Gallaghers Beer World/El Irlands. Pours a hazy amber/orange color with a medium white head that diminishes slowly. Aroma is fruity and hoppy with an overall grapefruit character. Notes of grapefruit, orange, tropical fruits, dark grasses, moss, citrus peel and hints of resin. Fine. Taste is fruity, with initial sweetness developing into an elegant bitterness that never overwhelms. Fruity flavors dominate especially grapefruit and orange. Bitterness comes from soft citrus and grassy flavors. Really good, well balanced and refined. Medium body, smooth and velvety. Low to mid carbonation. Alcohol well-hidden. Another fine beer by Mikkeller, nothing otherwordly but a well refined IIPA.
beer_name: Mikkeller Imperial India Pale Ale Centennial

review_blob: 355ml bottle from Club de Cervezas. Pours a hazy and pale yellow color with a big white head that diminishes quickly but laces well. Aroma is laid back, flowery, with lots of wheat and grainy malts and tiny hints of fruit and spice. Notes of hay, grain, bread, dried fruit and some soft citrus. Decent. Taste is neutral, bready with some small amount of spice and a fresh but indiscernible touch from the hops. Nothign extraordinary but well drinkable. Light bodied, medium carbonation. Quaffable. It has its space and time on a hot day, but its unlikely to satisfy if you look for complex aromas and explosion of flavors.

355ml bottle from Club de Cervezas. Pours a clear yellow color with a medium white head that diminishes quickly and leaves a small lacing. Aroma is weakly malty with almost no hop presence. Vaguely bready and grainy, weak, neutral with some evanescent floral hints. Not offensive, but really dull. Taste is quite watery and neutral as well. Almost no bitterness, bready and grainy. Dull. Inoffensive. Light bodied, mid-high carbonation. Refreshing and crisp. I really do not feel tempted to give this one higher scores. A great brewery making a dull beer where theres nothing to appreciate really. Its not just a style problem, since Schlenkerla Helles is a wonderful rendition of it.

355ml bottle from Club de Cervezas. Pours a beautiful and shiny orange color with a medium white frothy head with big bubbles and medium retention that leaves a fine lacing. Aroma is strongly hoppy, fruity and intense. Notes of grapefruit dominate leading to further perceptions of melon-pear, orange and tangerine citrus, hay, rare tropical fruit nectar, flowers, more citrus. Very aromatic. Taste starts with subtle fruity sweetness, mostly from sweet citrus flavors, leading to a very bitter finish that contains more citrus rind, orange peel and some lime/cedar touches. Alcohol warming. Lasting aftertaste. Wonderful. Body is medium to big, pretty sticky texture. Whole mouth remains sticky same as after drinking pressed overripe orange juice. Medium carbonation. Overall this is a fantastic sweet/citrusy IIPA that shows refinement and class, but needs a few extra kinks to be really sublime.

12fl. oz. bottle from Club de Cervezas. Pours a pitch black beer with a small light brown head that reduces to a small irregular film that lingers. Aroma is roasty, malty, very intense and luscious. Notes of cocoa and dark bitter chocolate prevail but layers of figs, prunes, blueberries, raisins and dates appear in full form. Extra layers of molasses and caramel. Quite complex and rich. Taste is sweet upfront with only mild roast in the back to offer some counterpunch. Even though its not as complex as the aroma, its a very refined sweetness. Flavors of dark fruits, burnt caramel, molasses prevail. Boozy and liquorish. Big body, smooth texture. A heavyweight Stout. Well integrated alcohol presence and godly warming effect. Low carbonation. A richly sweet and delicious Imperial Stout.
beer_name: Evil Twin I Love You With My Stout

review_blob: 355ml bottle from Club de Cervezas. Pours a hazy blonde/yellow color with a big white fully-lasting head that leaves a good cap. Aroma is fruity, hoppy and phenolic. Notes of pineapple, mango, rose-apple, tropical fruit salad, mellon, alcohol and peach. Too much alcohol for my taste. Taste is bitter with fruity sweetness and a strong alcoholic layer that prevails in the end. Flavors of tropical fruits, green bitter herbs, some pine and a finish of alcohol. Again too much. Since alcohol overpowers hops, its a weird IPA for me. Big body, smooth mouthfeel with medium carbonation. Aftertaste gets some more pine into the picture. I wouldnt say I dislike it, but I didnt love it. Its confusing and alcoholic. Bad bottle?

330ml bottle from Gallaghers Beer World/El Irlands. Pours a dark red color with a big and beautiful white head that diminishes slowly and leaves a nice film with a spiral design. Aroma is hoppy with some malty undertones. Notes of pine, red fruit marmalade, caramel, resin, spruce and a tad of toastiness. Interesting. Taste is strong with well-rounded bitterness and small semi-sweet traces. Piney flavors dominate giving way to some red fruitiness and touches of caramel. Flavorful but not refined. Medium body, medium carbonation and aftertaste. Overall this is a characterful and bold India Red Ale that doesnt shy away of showing its maltiness.

355ml bottle from Club de Cervezas. Pours a clear golden color with a medium white head that diminishes quickly but leaves an irregular film. Aroma is soft with mild flowery and fruity character. Notes of coriander, flowers, aniseed, hints of orange, palm syrup, rhubarb, honey and beetroot. Taste is moderately sweet, dry and a bit spicy. Flavors of orange are offset by spiciness, flowers and hidden bitter tones. Neutral biscuit and bready malts form a solid backbone. Tasty. Crisp and refreshing. High but soft carbonation. I drank this at a perfect time after a heavy work day in the sun... it was a real pleasure.

12 fl. oz. bottle from Club de Cervezas. Pours a clear golden color with a small white head that disappears quickly. Aroma is restrained with grain and hay dominating with soft herbal and flowery touches. Notes of lemongrass, bread, haystack, green garden herbs and some flowers. Quite weak. Taste has semi-bitter character, with biscuity flavors dominating hints of bread, grains, lemon and grass. Not bad but nothing outstanding here. Light bodied. Pretty dry finish, high carbonation. Crisp and refreshing. Drinkable. This is one efficient, by-the-book german-style Pils that doesnt show anything remarkable.

12fl. oz. bottle from Club de Cervezas. Pours a beautiful dark brown color with crimson hues. Head is creamy, medium, tan and long lasting, reducing into a solid lacing. Highly aromatic nose of dark sweet malts more toasted than roasted. Notes of rye bread, toasted grains, caramel, wet earth, dark tea leaves, raisins and dates. Really nice and hits a soft spot. Taste is semi sweet with some back-roasted sensation. Rich oatmeal flavors with hints of burnt sugars, caramel, raisins and dates. Delicious. Light body for a Stout. Highly drinkable with some alcoholic kick. Medium carbonation. Incredible drinkability. Overall a classy Stout on par with Samuel Smiths Oatmeal Stout and very similar to that one.
beer_name: Anderson Valley Barney Flats Oatmeal Stout

review_blob: 330ml bottle from Gallaghers Beer World/El Irlands. Pours a cloudy golden color with a medium white bubbly head that diminishes quickly leaving almost no lacing. Aroma is spicy with some hops. Notes of coriander, lemon zest, citrus rind, flowers, moss and traces of wheat grains. Nothing extraordinary but not bad. Taste is mellow, moderately spicy with a touch of green bitterness in the end. Coriander and citrus flavor dominate til the end which incorporates bitter garden herbs. Quite good. Light to medium body, lively carbonation, crisp and refreshing. Overall this is a very simple, slightly hoppy Witbier. Effective and refreshing but not expressive enough.

12fl oz. bottle from Club de Cervezas Pours a good-looking shiny golden color with orange-ish hues. Head is big white and lingering white head that recedes into a small cap. Aroma is really great, complex and characterful with a lot of barnyard, musty touches and some funk. Fruity esters dominate with mandarines, passion fruit and pommegranate shining above all else. Grapes and white wine give some additional complexity. Spicy traces come to the fore with warming, especially coriander, white pepper and some aromatic orange peel. Fantastic. Taste is mildly tart with fantastic fruity sweetness balancing out. Sour touches are complimented well by orange and grape flavors. A bit of spice of coriander and pepper. Chunks and bits of passionfruit and lemon. Amazing. Carbonation has a soft fizziness that caresses the tongue. Really smooth with a nice aftertaste. Massively drinkable. A bit champagnoise... A fantastic, complex Saison that I could drink every single day.

330ml bottle from Club de Cervezas. Pours a pitch black color with a big beige head that diminishes quickly but leaves a lasting film. Aroma is chocolatey, malty with a touch of smoke and dark fruits. Notes of dark chocolate, cocoa, chocolate powder, mokka and burnt sugar. Ashy traces and a bit of smoke round it up. Good. Taste is quite bitter in a bitter chocolate sense. Loads of chocolate and cocoa with some truffles and dark herbs (hops?). Roastiness overall. Lacks distinctiveness. Medium body, texture is pretty thick and quite heavy for the ABV. Medium carbonation. Long aftertaste. A good Stout that reminded me of Selva Negra Stout from Valdivia.

750ml bottle from Gallaghers Beer World/El Irlands. Pours a nice, beautiful bright orange color with a big white creamy head that lasts for long and laces well. Aroma is strong, fruity and with some lasting grainy-malty presence. Notes of peach melba, pineapple, raspberries, orange marmalade, mango, hay and papaya. Taste is mostly sweet, well balanced with an explosion of fruity flavors, again with peaches, oranges, raspberries and sweet cherries dominating. Extra hints of candy sugar and some bread. Big body, soft carbonation. Aftertaste is pretty mellow. This one is a nice fruity Barley Wine.

330ml bottle from Club de Cervezas. Pours a beautiful shiny orange color with a big white frothy and long lasting head that leaves a nice lacing and a film. Aroma is richly hoppy, green and citrusy. Predominant notes of resin, pine, lemon zest, lime, green mango, kiwi and herbs. Fresh and strong, with lemon peel dominating even after warming and without ever losing any of the green edge. Taste is bitter a plenty, citrusy and zesty. Strong lemon and lemongrass flavors later incorporate green mango, kiwi, pine and some soft earthy traces. Good. Medium body, lighter than expected. Soft carbonation. Alcohol kept in check very well. I expected something bigger from Granizo, but its still a very solid, efficient IIPA. Just not the best from the brewery.

330ml bottle from Gallaghers Beer World/El Irlands as "To From Via". Pours an impenetrable deep dark brown color with a big light brown medium lasting head that leaves no lacing. Aroma is intensely spicy with strong toasted character. Notes of brown sugars, burnt caramel, cinnamon, aniseed, orange peel, clove, coriander, toasted bread and toasted grains. Taste is highly spicy, sticky with lots of roasted bitterness. Moderate sugary sweetness is offset by burnt notes. Spicy flavors come in the shape of cinnamon, clove and aniseed mostly, but you also get through some orange peel, rye and christmas cake touches. Good. Quite sticky. Medium to big body. Syrupy texture. Medium carbonation. Bitter in the finish and aftertaste which leaves a long spicy sensation. Pretty nice, flavorful, strongly spiced, but rather unfocused Christmas ale.
beer_name: Mikkeller X-mas Porter 2015 Fra Via Til (From Via To)

review_blob: 355ml can from Club de Cervezas. Pours a clear golden color with a medium white frothy head that disappears quickly leaving tiny, thin bubbles. Aroma is freshly fruity and floral with a strong maltiness. Notes of flowers, pineapple, honey coated green apples, biscuits, white bread and wheat. Nice and well balanced. Taste is also fresh, semi-sweet with shy end bitterness. Mild neutral tasting pineapple flavor with some spiciness and malt providing stronger notes of biscuit, cereal grains and bread. Nice. Light bodied, low carbonation. Short, quick finish and aftertaste. A good, quaffable, interesting Wheat Beer.

330ml bottle from Gallaghers Beer World/El Irlands. Pours impenetrable dark brown, almost black, color with a small light brown head that disappears quickly and leaves no lacing. Aroma is strong on roasted malts. Notes of roasted coffee beans, burnt caramel, almond liquor, sherry, licorice and lactose. Some dark green herbs give this one an almost Jgermeister quality. Strange. Not bad. Taste is mellow, mildly sweet with lactose very present in the beginning. Soft coffee-ish flavors come through in the middle with some almond, liquor and green herbs shining towards the end. A roasted note is left behind as aftertaste. Smooth, velvety body. Very soft carbonation, almost not there. Alcohol has a pleasant warming effect. Overall this is an interesting and different Sweet Stout that reminded me a lot of Jgermeister+coffee.

355ml can from Club de Cervezas. Pours a deep dark brown color with a medium tan head that lasts for a while and laces well. Aroma is nicely toasted, with rich bready malts and just the right amount of coconut. Notes of rye and whole-grain bread, toasted grains, coconut, some caramel and nuts. Really nice, rich and fulfilling. Taste is gently sweet, bready, toasted and grainy. A little touch of coconut, but not invasive at all. Nice with a velvety mouthfeel and a dry finish. Alcohol compliments the flavor really well. Medium body, soft carbonation. Tasty. This one is a really nice sessionable Porter. Another excellent one from our fellow Polynesian island brewers.

330ml bottle from Gallaghers Beer World/El Irlands. Pours a hazy orange color with a big off-white head that lingers leaving a nice lacing. Aroma is freshly hoppy, dark green and pungent with intense piney, resinous character. Notes of spruce, resin, tobacco, cannabis and kiwi. Lacks some brightness but its still interesting. Taste is very bitter with some soft and gentle fruity sweetness. Most flavors continue the aroma profile giving resinous, piney bitter touches and hints of grass, green herbs and kiwi. Medium body, soft carbonation. Quite dry and refreshing. Medium to long aftertaste. One of the best of the Mikkeller Single-Hop series. Tasty, intense but a bit one-dimensional.

330ml bottle from Gallaghers Beer World/El Irlands. Pours a hazy orange color with a big white creamy head that lasts long and laces well. Aroma is hoppy, a bit evanescent, with fruity and floral traces. Notes of apple, pear, cider, flowers, weak citrus and white grapes. Warming brings some bubble-gum touches. OK. Not very expressive but not disagreeable either. Taste is medium bitter with slightly tart touches. Cidery notes come through and mix up with the lemongrass flavors. A trace of sweetness comes from the effective malty backbone. Lacking. Medium body, soft to mid carbonation. Alcohol unnoticeable. A drinkable but subpar IPA that does not express Nelson Sauvin in all its might.
beer_name: Mikkeller Single Hop Nelson Sauvin IPA

review_blob: 330ml bottle from Gallaghers Beer World/El Irlands. Pours a beautiful orange color with a big long lasting off-white head that laces well. Aroma is hoppy, green, with clear notes of kiwi, prickly pear, melon pear, lemongrass, green leaves, some tobacco and moss. Small hints of grainy malt with minor fruity peachy traces. Taste is reasonably bitter, bright and lively, with nice semi-sweet fruity counterbalance. Flavors of kiwi, soft citrus, peach, grass, leaves and some earth. Nice! Medium body, soft carbonation. Balanced. Mild short-lived aftertaste. A good, tasty IPA. Chinook is really well manifested. So far this one is the most expressive of the Mikkeller Single Hop series Ive tried. Lets see if the Simcoe one can surpass it.

355ml can from Club de Cervezas. Pours a clear golden color with a big white frothy head that diminishes quickly and leaves a thin lacing. Aroma is hoppy, clean and well-defined with citrusy notes dominating. Hints of lemon, lime, zest, cedar, pine spruce, prickly pear and grass. Good, refreshing, solid. Taste is medium bitter with citrus again taking the center spot. Lemony touches mix up with grassy and herbal bitterness. Refreshing, but mild for expectations. Body is light to medium with alcohol unnoticeable despite the big 7% abv. Soft carbonation. A nice, refreshing IPL but a bit one-dimensional and nothing extraordinary.
beer_name: Ballast Point Fathom India Pale Lager

review_blob: 355ml can from Club de Cervezas Pours a hazy amber color with a medium off white head that diminishes slowly into a thin lacing. Aroma is well balanced with strong hop character and intense cereal graininess. Notes of grains, hay, bread crust, grapefruit, pine, citrus. Nice balance and really fresh and crisp. Taste is pretty bitter with some fruity sweetness in the beginning. Strong, bold and characterful. Finish has nice herbal/citrusy bitterness that lingers into the aftertaste. Light to medium body, soft carbonation. Alcohol well integrated. A really good refreshing APA that deserves more recognition.

330cl bottle from Club de Cervezas as Barista Chocolate Quad. Pours a clear, bright mahogany color with a small off-white fizzy head that decays quickly and leaves a good lacing. Aroma is really nice, with strong toasted malts. Coffee-dominated notes, rough Arabica coffee-grains, coffee-cherries, toasted coffee, with coffee-liquor and smaller hints of bitter chocolate, truffles, figs and prunes. Some phenols come through although not in a disturbing way. Taste is coffee dominated but with much stronger presence of dark fruits, especially blueberries, plums, prunes and figs. Nice, strong finish and aftertaste. Unfortunately, the mouthfeel is a little bit dull. Light body, a bit watery which makes alcohol much more noticeable. Its not just warming, its felt on other levels too. "Chocolate Quad" my ass. It is nowhere near in mouthfeel to a Quad. This would be the downside but in general I still like it. A coffee-infused Belgian, very unique and different.

355ml can from Club de Cervezas. Pours a beautiful clear orange color with a big white frothy head that diminishes slowly and leaves a nice cap. Aroma is intensely hoppy, fruity and citrusy. Huge notes of mandarines, tangerines, oranges and grapefruit upfront and backed up by hints of green herbs, grains, white bread and mellon nectar. Delicious. Taste is mostly bitter, expressive and showcasing sweet citrus fruitiness in harmony with herbal and grassy touches. Nice neutral bready backbone. Body does not feel that light, considering how punchy this one is. You would never believe its 3.8% abv. Medium carbonation, strong finish and aftertaste. Definitely an excellent session IPA showing remarkable craftsmanship.

330ml bottle from Club de Cervezas Pours a cloudy pinkish amber with floating particles and a big white frothy head. Aroma is hoppy with accompanying neutral bready malts. Notes of fresh herbs, cucumber, earth, leaves, citrus and lemongrass. Very American. Taste is bitter, like a session IPA. Flavorful with lots of citrus and herbs. Bready malts give solid backbone. Light to medium body. Its one of the best APAs in Chile, definetely.

355 ml can from Club de Cervezas. Pours a mostly clear dark orange/amber color with a big white fluffy head that diminishes slowly and leaves a nice film. Aroma is pretty impressive with clean hops and some potent malt sugars mixing up to give a powerful fruity nose. Notes of grapefruit followed up by orange, tangerines, leaf, hay a bit of honey and watermelon. Taste is bitter with marginal grainy and fruity sweetness giving some counterbalance. Grapefruit flavors dominate throughout. It leaves a long herbal bitter aftertaste. Delicious. Medium body. Alcohol is high but it gives only a minmal warming hint. Carbonation is soft. Would it be better with some extra prickliness? I think so. Its a delightful and intense straight-forward and fruity American IPA.

355ml can from Club de Cervezas. Pours a clear yellow-gold color with a big white fizzy head that disappears really quick leaving no lacing at all. Aroma is really strange with upfront yeasty and tart notes. Evanescent and diluted at times, but with warming it becomes slightly clearer. Hints of Champagne, apples, cider, funk, barnyard and green herbal aromas. Not really bad, but I did not get much "Ale" character. Taste is mildly sour, with no sweetness and clear salty presence especially in the very dry finish. Flavors again remind of cider and Champagne with some tart apples and decent funkiness. OK. But lacks character. Light body, high carbonation, its quite refreshing really but it was quite different from what I expected. Cant say I loved it. Not bad. Not sure how well it fits in the style.
beer_name: Anderson Valley Highway 128 The Kimmie, The Yink, and the Holy Gose

review_blob: 330ml bottle from Gallaghers Beer World/El Irlands. Pours a dark amber color with a small off white airy head that disappears quickly leaving only isolate bubbles. Weird! Aroma is earthy, woody and mossy, with notes of overripe peach, goldenberry, bitter orange, grapefruit, mango and rosehip. A little bit messy and quite diluted with some pervasive phenolic hints. It might be a bad bottle though it says bbd: Feb 2017. Taste is moderately bitter with some accompanying tartness. Fruity flavors dominate with even semi-sweet touches. Tropical and overripe fruits, oranges and even tart apples with a continuing earthy aura. Clearly not in the best shape or maybe a bad batch. Medium body, soft carbonation. Really disappointing and mediocre. Tomahawk hops did not shine at all here. Must re-rate a fresher one.

330ml bottle from Gallaghers Beer World/El Irlands. Pours a mostly clear amber with a big white head that shows long retention and leaves a thick film. Nose has a green hoppy aroma of lemongrass, lime and grapefruit. Mild resinous notes in the back and stronger green fruity notes kiwi, aloe vera and zest. Good but really soft. Not expressive enough. Taste has mild green bitterness. Herbal, citrusy and some soft fruity flavors. Lemon, grapefruit, kiwi and custard apple notes integrate into the overall citrusy expression. Medium body and soft carbonation. Moderate astringency and unnoticeable alcohol. This one seemed pleasant enough but slightly dull, lacking fun. Is Cascade too mellow for a single hop American-style IPA? Id have to try another example.

355ml bottle from Club de Cervezas. Pours a clear/filtered golden color with a big white head that diminishes slowly and leaves a small cap. Aroma is hoppy but with a good, strong malty backbone. Intense fruity notes of pineapple, mango, peach and melon start right away but vanish after a few minutes. With warming, an even stronger nose of hay, goldenberry and most of all pungent resin and pine become the dominant feature. Begins like a well-hopped Barley Wine but becomes more IIPA later. Nice! Taste is well-balanced with initial sweet fruity malts and more bitter middle and finish. Very flavorful with notes of tropical fruits and later pungent resinous touches. The powerful fruity bitterness is exacerbated by bits of alcohol. Again, a fine taste. Body is medium to big with a soft to medium carbonation and an overall oily texture. Some nice alcohol warming. This one is a beautiful IIPA with two personalities: Fruitier while cooler and resinous when warmer. Very good but not extraordinary...

355ml can from Club de Cervezas. Pours an unfiltered hazy yellow color with a small white head that diminishes quickly and laces small. Soft malty and hoppy aroma, well-balanced with notes of flowers, grains, baked bread, biscuit, cardboard and hay. Problem is that its very subdued, restrained. Not bad but too shy! Taste is mostly neutral with bready, grainy sweetness and scarce to no bitterness. Flavors of grain, bread, pumpkin and even sweet potato. A bit watery. Timid. Relatively clean, crisp taste. Medium carbonation. Lacks distinctive character by having either a stronger, heavier malty profile or greener hops. Overall an OK summer refreshment but nothing to write home about.
